title: How to Switch to 3G on Samsung, Google Pixel, & Other Androids

steps.title: Open your phone's Settings.
steps.content: Open your phone's Settings. Tap the Settings app if it is on your home screen. If not, tap on Applications , and tap on the Settings app icon from your app drawer. Alternatively, you can swipe down from the top-right corner of your screen to open the quick panel. From here, you can tap on the cogwheel icon to be taken to your phone's Settings app.

steps.title: Tap Connections.
steps.content: Tap Connections . It's near the top of the Settings app menu.

steps.title: Tap Mobile networks.
steps.content: Tap Mobile networks . It's near the bottom of the Connections menu.

steps.title: Tap Network mode.
steps.content: Tap Network mode . If you don't have a Network mode option, you can't choose the exact network your phone connects to. You can, however, toggle off Allow 5G service to prevent your phone from using 5G. It will be forced to use 4G or 3G instead.

steps.title: Choose 3G.
steps.content: Choose 3G . Some Samsung Galaxy models won't let you specifically choose 3G , but will require you to choose an option that includes a range of network types. If this is the case, you cannot force your phone to only use 3G, but you can encourage it to use 3G more by choosing a network mode that includes the least amount of network types possible. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. Tap the Settings app if it is on your home screen. If not, tap on Applications , and tap on the Settings app icon from your app drawer. Alternatively, you can swipe down from the top-right corner of your screen to open the quick panel. From here, you can open the Settings app.

steps.title: Tap Network & internet.
steps.content: Tap Network & internet . It's near the top of your Settings menu.

steps.title: Tap SIMs.
steps.content: Tap SIMs . It's also near the top of the Network & internet menu, and has an icon of a SIM card.

steps.title: Tap Preferred network type.
steps.content: Tap Preferred network type . You will have to scroll to find this option. Your currently selected preferred network type will be shown as well, in a smaller font.

steps.title: Choose 3G.
steps.content: Choose 3G . Your phone will now only connect to 3G networks. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. Tap the Settings app if it is on your home screen. If not, tap on Applications , and tap on the Settings app icon from your app drawer. You may also be able to swipe down or up on your device to open the quick panel, which has an icon to go to Settings.

steps.title: Go to Mobile Networks.
steps.content: Go to Mobile Networks . Under Wireless and Networks , tap on Mobile Networks . Depending on your phone type, the wording of the menu options may be slightly different depending on the model.

steps.title: Tap on Preferred network type.
steps.content: Tap on Preferred network type . Here youâ€™ll get options for the type of connections your device will always use. The wording of the menu option may vary depending on what phone you have.

steps.title: Switch to 3G.
steps.content: Switch to 3G. From the options, choose 3G . It may also be called CDMA on some Android models. Some Android phone may not let you specifically pick 3G, and you may have to pick an option that combines multiple network types.
